Name: Thiacloprid
Description: Thiacloprid is a nitrile that is cyanamide in which the hydrogens are replaced by a 1,3-thiazolidin-2-ylidene group which in turn is substituted by a (6-chloropyridin-3-yl)methyl group at the ring nitrogen. It has a role as a xenobiotic, an environmental contaminant and a neonicotinoid insectide. It is a member of thiazolidines, a nitrile and a monochloropyridine. It is functionally related to a 2-chloropyridine and a cyanamide.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Quingkui F et al; J Agric Food Chem 65(8): 1483-1488 (2017) (2) Zhang Z et al; J Agric Food Chem 64: 9276-85 (2016)
plant_concentrations.Value: Thiacloprid half-life in honeysuckle flowers was reported at 4.1 days and in leaves at 1.1 days following application of the recommended dose. At the recommended dose, thiacloprid was reported as a residue at an average concentration of 0.55 mg/kg 7 days following application and at 0.022 mg/kg 14 days following application to honeysuckle plants. At two times the recommended dose, thiacloprid was reported as a residue at an average concentration of 1.37 mg/kg 7 days following application and at 0.046 mg/kg 14 days following application to honeysuckle plants. Sun, shade, and oven drying techniques were tested for the degradation effects on the drying process in tea-making, resulting in the percentage of digestion ranging from 37.7% to 77.3%. Thiacloprid was applied to honeysuckle samples, let stand for 1 hour, and then brewed in tea for 2 to 60 minutes. The percentage of thiacloprid transferred from leaves to tea ranged from 16.1% to 23.4%(1). The half-life of thiacloprid in cotton leaves grown from treated seeds is about 3 days(2).

animal_concentrations.Value: Thiacloprid was not detected (quantification limit 2-10 ng/mL) in blood samples from 30 nestlings of Eurasian eagle owl (Bubo Bubo) in Spain(1).

plant_translocations.content: The present study aimed to investigate the distribution and migration of eleven systemic and non-systemic pesticides between the skin and pulp of apples. It also examined the behavior of these pesticides during thermal processes ranging from 40°C to 150°C in two apple varieties. Gas and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry were employed for analytical investigations. Variations in pesticide concentrations between the pulp and skin were observed depending on the apple variety. Pirimicarb showed the highest transfer to the pulp, while boscalid and deltamethrin remained predominantly on the skin. Surprisingly, boscalid was found to be more present in the apple skin than in the pulp. Drying and dry pasteurization processes were the most effective in reducing pesticide levels in apples with and without skin, respectively. Thermal processes resulted in processing factors ranging from 0.06 to 0.98 for ten pesticides, with acetamiprid being the only pesticide whose levels were not decreased. The study discussed the relationship between pesticide distribution, behavior, and physico-chemical properties, particularly water solubility. The findings contribute to a better understanding of pesticide efficacy and removal in apples.
plant_translocations.reference: Hrynko, I., Kaczyński, P., Pietruszyńska, M., & Łozowicka, B. (2023). The effect of food thermal processes on the residue concentration of systemic and non-systemic pesticides in apples. Food Control, 143, 109267.

method.Chemical Preparation: Eleven systemic and non-systemic pesticides - pirimicarb, boscalid, deltamethrin, and 8 others (not specified)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Pesticides applied to apple skin surface.  Fruit prepared in such a manner was subjected to artificial inoculation through submersion for 8 h in a solution containing selected plant protection products.
method.Other information and Other Information: Study investigated distribution of pesticides between skin and pulp using GC/LC-MS/MS analysis. Relates pesticide behavior to physico-chemical properties like water solubility

plant_translocations.result: [{"Size": "Medium-size apple", "% in apple pulp": 34.6, "% in apple skin": 65.4}, {"Size": "Large-size apple", "% in apple pulp": 0.0, "% in apple skin": 100.0}]

plant_translocations.content: We conducted uptake experiments with 12 different organic chemicals using 16 plant species and observed variations in their ability to take up and translocate these chemicals. The shoot and root concentrations of each chemical varied among the plant species. Root concentration factor values increased with an increasing log of the n-octanol-water partition coefficient (log Kow) of the organic chemicals, suggesting that root concentrations may be predicted to some extent based on log Kow. Root-to-shoot translocation was also related to log Kow, as the shoot-to-root concentration ratio decreased with increasing log Kow. However, the relationship between shoot concentration factor value and log Kow was not clear and differed among plant species.
plant_translocations.reference: Namiki, S., Otani, T., Motoki, Y., Seike, N., & Iwafune, T. (2018). Differential uptake and translocation of organic chemicals by several plant species from soil. Journal of pesticide science, 43(2), 96-107.

method.Test Plant: Hordeum distichon, Zea mays L., Glycine max Merrill, Phaseolus vulgaris L., Brassica oleracea L. var. capitata, Brassica rapa L. war. peruviridis, Chrysanthemum coronarium L., Lactuca sativa L., Allissms wakegi Araki, Apium graveolens L. war. dulce, Solanum lycopersicum Mill., Capsicum grossism, Cucumtis sativis L., Cucurbita maxima Duch., Spinacia oleracea L., and Beta vulgaris L. var. cicla.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds germinated in nursery soil in growth chamber at 20°C, 14:10 hr light:dark cycle. Seedlings transplanted at 7-28 days into test soil pots and grown for 21 more days under same conditions. Soil moisture maintained at 50-70% water holding capacity (WHC).
method.Chemical Preparation: 12 organic chemicals (10 pesticides, β-HCH, dieldrin) with log Kow -0.6 to 5 dissolved in acetone at 50 mg/L. 1 L mixture added to 278g Celite powder, acetone evaporated leaving 92.6-133.6 μg/g of each chemical on Celite.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 450g uncontaminated soil mixed with 5g chemical-loaded Celite in 600 mL pots. Fertilized with chemical fertilizer and dolomite. Final concentrations ranged 81.0-129.7 μg/pot.
method.Other Information: Plants grown to obtain 1-2g root dry weight per species. At 21 days, shoots and roots harvested, fresh weights measured, divided into subsamples to determine moisture content and chemical concentrations.
